section-block.rac_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Alma and How She Got Her Name

section-block.rac_book_title_hed_theme_4_two-lines: Alma and How She Got Her Name
section-block.rac_book_summary: Alma thinks her name is too long. She thinks it never fits. So, her father tells her the story of each of her names and the family member who has the name. In the end, Alma decides that her name fits just right.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Me and you | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Gather children and welcome them. Tell them that they will learn new words, play fun activities and meet new friends! Talk to children about names.
Invite children to play the name game. Say, “My name is ______.” Then clap and point to the person next to you and say, “What’s your name?”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal.
Meet Scout the Squirrel. He will read our books with us. Scout loves to read narratives. In this book, Scout will read about a family.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Do you think Alma likes her name? Why or why not?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Alma’s father asks her to listen to his story and then decide if her name fits. What do you think she will decide?
What kinds of things did Alma’s grandmother like? Do you like any of those things?
Why does Alma think she is like her grandmother Sofia?
Alma draws like her grandfather José. What do you do like someone in your family?
Alma is named after five people in her family. Who in your family has the same name as you?
Say your name aloud. Say “I am _______ , and I have a story to tell!”
Let’s turn and talk and answer the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Do you think Alma likes her name? Why or why not?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Yes. Because she thinks her name fits her just right.
No. Because she thinks her name is too long.
Yes. Because she loves the story of her name.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about your own name. What does it say about you?

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Alma not like her name because it was too long or short?
Alma did not like her name because it’s too l_____ (long).
Alma does not like her name because it’s too long.
What did Alma find out about her name?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Keeping beloved keepsakes in the classroom can help children transition from the home and into preK. Familiar items, such as family photos or a favorite book, can be useful in making a new place seem less overwhelming. Letting the children know the schedule will also help them be less nervous.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Me and you | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make and Keep Relationships
section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they like about their friends. Invite children to talk about the special things they like to do together. What do they do when they’re getting to know other children? Discuss the different ways in which people can build good relationships.
Introduce a new word and a phrase.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread some of the pages from Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal.
Clifford loves his own name. He also loves to build relationships with his family and friends.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book. Then we can talk about Alma’s relationships with the other people in the story. (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Alma’s daddy tell a story?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit tell a story Vocabulary Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Alma’s daddy tells her a story about Sophia. Alma’s daddy had a good relationship with Sophia. What did Sophia teach Alma’s daddy to do? (MB)
Look at the picture of Alma and her daddy. Do you think they have a good relationship? How can you tell? (MB)
What did Esperanza’s son do? Did Esperanza do the same thing? How do you know?
Alma’s daddy told her stories about her family. What did Alma learn about her family? Did that make her feel better about her name? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to play a game of Telephone. Line children up and give the first child a short sentence about what it means to be a good friend. Then, have the first child whisper the sentence to the child behind them in line. Then have that child whisper the sentence to the next child, and so on. When you get to the end of the line, have that child say the sentence out loud so everyone can see how much it changed from one person to the next. Listening closely to others is an important part of building relationships.
Transcribe children’s speech as they complete the following prompt: I like to [bake cookies] with my [grandmother].

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making and keeping relationships is an important part of social development and one that you should focus on throughout the year. Children can learn to engage in strong, trusting relationships with you and other adults in their lives as well as with their classmates. It’s important to use activities during the day that will help children develop empathy for others (Boyarshinov/frogstreet.com).

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Me and you | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Why is it important to always listen and remember?
Focus on vocabulary by playing a jumping game. Have children stand. Make up short sentences that include the word “joy.” Tell children to jump when they hear the word.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to revisit Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal.
Scout loves Alma and How She Got Her Name because he likes to learn about how people got their names.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we learn about other people?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on Listening and Remembering
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Alma’s daddy start telling her about the people in her family?
Esperanza hoped to travel. Did she do it? How do you know?
The author says that Esperanza “never left the city where she was born.” Who in her family left the city? Where did that person go?
What did Alma’s grandfather José do early each morning?
Candela is Alma’s grandmother. How many grandmothers does Alma have? What is Alma’s other grandmother’s name?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Did you listen and remember as we read the story today?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s see how much you remember as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we learn about other people?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share their thinking.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can learn from family stories.
We can learn by listening to others.
We can learn by asking questions.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about the different ways they can learn about others.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you learn about other people by asking questions?
I can learn about other people by asking qu_________ (questions).
I can learn about other people by asking questions.
What family stories do you know?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Listening and remembering are the first building blocks to comprehension and literacy among young children. Make sure that children are paying attention to what you and others say when you are together. Reading aloud daily gets children interested in the characters’ stories as well as their own stories and the stories of others.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Me and you | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_4: Talk About What You Like to Do
section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what different people like to do. Discuss how doing things they like can make them happy.
Tell children to pretend that they only like things with names that start with the same sound as their own names. Model with your name.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I like to. . . . It is an informational text in the form of a poster. Informational texts give true facts.
Scout loves to look at informational posters. They give great information!
Alma and How She Got Her Name and I like to . . . both talk about things that different people like to do. Let’s see if we can find any other connections.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this
week’s concept question:
What makes us who we are?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to All About Me
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Big Chart. Then use the following prompts to discuss the poster. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl is trying to catch the ball. What games do you like to play with a ball?
What is the girl using to draw? What shapes do you see in her drawing?
The boy is reading a book. What kind of books do you like to
read? How do you feel when you read your favorite book? (MB)
Who can come point to the children who are eating pizza? Name a food that you like to eat. Do the children in this picture look happy or sad? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to play charades. Children would think of something they like to do and then act it out for the other children without using any words. Challenge the children watching to guess what it is that the child likes to do. Model for children.
Provide a writing prompt about something children like to do with their families. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Being able to identify emotions in others is a critical part of children’s emotional development. The more children listen to Alma’s story, they will start to understand that other people have perspectives and feelings different from their own. Provide as many opportunities as you can to help children identify other people’s feelings.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Me and you | WEEK 1: All About Me

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out the movements of painting pictures on the wall like Alma and her grandfather. Have them reach up high and then go down low to paint.
Sing the song B-I-N-G-O with children. Ask children if they think Bingo is a good name for a dog. Why or why not? Ask children to share the names they like better.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Alma and How She Got Her Name by Juana Martinez-Neal.
This book is a narrative. That means it is a story that the author made up, but it may be based on something that actually happened. Scout loves to read narrative stories.
This week, we read all about Alma and where her long name came from. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can learning the story of your name make you feel?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Alma thinks her name is too long. Does she feel happy or sad about her name? Show the look she has on her face. (MB)
Alma’s daddy talks about how his father, José, walked to the mountains. Let’s pretend to walk to the mountains.
Alma likes to draw just like her grandfather. She draws a cat for her daddy. What do you draw?
Alma is wearing a red string around her wrist. Why is she wearing it?
At the end of the book, Alma says she loves the story of her name. She thinks it fits her just right.
How do you think Alma feels? Show the look she has on her face.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
How can learning the story of your name make you feel?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Knowing the story of my name can make me feel happy.
Knowing the story of my name can make me feel proud.
Knowing the story of my name can make me feel special.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about the different people in their families.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can learning about your name make you feel happy?
Learning about my name can make me feel h_____ (happy).
Learning about my name can make me feel happy.
How could learning the story of your name make you feel special?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: People from different parts of the world have different names, live in different places, and have different traditions. Emphasize the importance of accepting and respecting the differences between people from different parts of the world.
